message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Strictly local phonological processes
Paper Abstract: This dissertation identifies a strong computational property of phonological and morphological processes with local triggers. It is shown that the input-output mapping that underlies these processes can be modeled with Strictly Local (SL) functions, a previously undefined class of subregular relations. The SL functions, which are divided into two proper subclasses of subsequential functions (the Input SL functions and Output SL functions) are given an automata-theoretic characterization by combining the properties of subsequential transduction (Mohri, 1997) and the Strictly Local formal languages (McNaughton and Papert, 1971; Rogers and Pullum, 2011; Rogers et al., 2013). Importantly, the property of strict locality is independent of and compatible with both rule- and constraint-based grammatical formalisms, since it holds of the input-output mappings that both formalisms describe. The range of processes that are shown to be Strictly Local includes substitution, deletion, insertion, synchronic metathesis, local partial reduplication, and general affixation. This computational property aids in identifying the set of 'phonologically possible' processes within the larger set of logically possible processes. In addition, a learning algorithm that provably learns the class of ISL functions by using strict locality as an inductive principle is presented. These combined contributions to typology and learning demonstrate how computational analysis can enhance our understanding of the nature of locality in phonological processes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Strictly local formal languages"

Links: [{"title":"Local language (formal language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_language_(formal_language)"},{"title":"Formal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language"},{"title":"Formal grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_grammars"},{"title":"LL grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LL1_grammar"},{"title":"Category:Formal languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_languages"},{"title":"Template talk:Formal languages and grammars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Formal_languages_and_grammars"},{"title":"Regular grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_grammar"},{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Chomsky hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chomsky_hierarchy"},{"title":"Purely functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purely_functional_programming"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about strictly local formal languages:

## Definition

A local language is a formal language for which membership of a word in the language can be determined by looking at the first and last symbol and each two-symbol substring of the word.

## Formal Specification

A language L over an alphabet A is defined to be local if there are subsets R and S of A and a subset F of A×A such that a word w is in L if and only if the first letter of w is in R, the last letter of w is in S and no factor of length 2 in w is in F.

## Recognition and Classification

A local language isrecognised by a local automaton, a particular kind of deterministic finite automaton.(no content)A local language is 2-testable, where a k-testable language is one for which membership of a word depends only on the prefix and suffix of length k and the set of factors of w of length k.

## Closure Properties

The family of local languages over A is closed under intersection and Kleene star, but not complement, union or concatenation.

## Relationship to Regular Languages

Every regular language not containing the empty string is the image of a local language under a strictly alphabetic morphism.

Here are the web search results for **phonological processes**:

## Overview

Phonological processes are systematic transformations in how sounds are produced, and they reflect typical strategies used to simplify language as phonological systems develop.

## Main Types of Phonological Processes

Phonological rules can be roughly divided into four types: Assimilation, when a sound changes one of its features to be more similar to an adjacent sound. Dissimilation occurs when a sound changes one of its features to become less similar to an adjacent sound, usually to make the two sounds more distinguishable. Insertion is when an extra sound is added between two others. Deletion occurs when a sound, such as a stress-less syllable or a weak consonant, is not pronounced.

## Characteristics of Phonological Rules

Phonological rules apply even to new words, and speakers apply these rules without being aware of it, acquiring the rules early in life without any explicit teaching.

## In Child Language Development

Common phonological processes in children include patterns like reduplication, final consonant deletion, and cluster reduction. These processes reflect typical strategies children use to simplify adult words as their phonological systems develop.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about machine learning algorithms:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Types of Machine Learning Algorithms

Modern-day Machine Learning algorithms are broken into 3 algorithm types: Supervised Learning Algorithms, Unsupervised Learning Algorithms, and Reinforcement Learning Algorithms.

**Supervised Learning:** Current Supervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of classification and regression.

**Unsupervised Learning:** Current Unsupervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of clustering, dimensionality reduction, and association rule.

**Reinforcement Learning:** Current Reinforcement Learning Algorithms focus on decisions that must be made with respect to some previous, unknown time and are broken down to either be studies of model-based methods or model-free methods.

## Specific Algorithm Examples

Some notable machine learning algorithms include:
- Support vector machines (SVMs, also support vector networks) are supervised max-margin models with associated learning algorithms that analyze data for classification and regression analysis.
- Deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

Links: [{"title":"Transduction (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Transduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction"},{"title":"Signal transduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_transduction"},{"title":"Transduction (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction_(genetics)"},{"title":"Transduction (biophysics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction_(biophysics)"},{"title":"Transduction (physiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction_(physiology)"},{"title":"Transducer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transducer"},{"title":"Transformation geometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformation_geometry"},{"title":"Transfer principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_principle"},{"title":"Transposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposition"}]

Based on the search results, here's what transduction means in mathematics and related fields:

## Mathematical Definition

In the context of machine learning and logic, transduction or transductive inference is reasoning from observed, specific (training) cases to specific (test) cases. In contrast, induction is reasoning from observed training cases to general rules, which are then applied to the test cases.

## Key Characteristics

Transduction has the advantage of being able to consider all of the points, not just the labeled points, while performing the labeling task, and transductive algorithms would label the unlabeled points according to the clusters to which they naturally belong. 

An advantage of transduction is that it may be able to make better predictions with fewer labeled points, because it uses the natural breaks found in the unlabeled points. However, one disadvantage of transduction is that it builds no predictive model; if a previously unknown point is added to the set, the entire transductive algorithm would need to be repeated with all of the points in order to predict a label.

## Historical Context

Transduction was introduced in a computer science context by Vladimir Vapnik in the 1990s. Examples of transductive algorithms include the k-nearest neighbor algorithm and the Transductive Support Vector Machine (TSVM).

Based on the web search results, here's information about affixation in linguistics:

## Definition

In linguistics, an affix is a morpheme that is attached to a word stem to form a new word or word form. Affixation is the process of adding these morphemes to words.

## Types of Affixes

The main two categories are derivational and inflectional affixes.

**Derivational Affixes:** Derivational affixes, such as un-, -ation, anti-, pre- etc., introduce a semantic change to the word they are attached to. For example, morphological derivation is the process of forming a new word from an existing word, often by adding a prefix or suffix, such as un- or -ness. For example, unhappy and happiness derive from the root word happy.

**Inflectional Affixes:** In English most nouns are inflected for number with the inflectional plural affix -s (as in "dog" → "dog-s"), and most English verbs are inflected for tense with the inflectional past tense affix -ed (as in "call" → "call-ed").

## Affix Positions

Affixes can appear in different positions relative to word stems:
- A prefix (write → re-write; lord → over-lord) rarely changes the lexical category in English.
- An infix is an affix inserted inside a word stem (an existing word or the core of a family of words).
- A suprafix is a type of affix that gives a suprasegmental pattern (such as tone, stress, or nasalization) to either a neutral base or a base with a preexisting suprasegmental pattern.

Based on the web search results, here's information about affixation in linguistics:

## Definition

In linguistics, an affix is a morpheme that is attached to a word stem to form a new word or word form. Affixation is the process of adding these morphemes to words.

## Types of Affixes

The main two categories are derivational and inflectional affixes.

**Derivational Affixes:** Derivational affixes, such as un-, -ation, anti-, pre- etc., introduce a semantic change to the word they are attached to. For example, morphological derivation is the process of forming a new word from an existing word, often by adding a prefix or suffix, such as un- or -ness. For example, unhappy and happiness derive from the root word happy.

**Inflectional Affixes:** In English most nouns are inflected for number with the inflectional plural affix -s (as in "dog" → "dog-s"), and most English verbs are inflected for tense with the inflectional past tense affix -ed (as in "call" → "call-ed").

## Affix Positions

Affixes can appear in different positions relative to word stems:
- A prefix (write → re-write; lord → over-lord) rarely changes the lexical category in English.
- An infix is an affix inserted inside a word stem (an existing word or the core of a family of words).
- A suprafix is a type of affix that gives a suprasegmental pattern (such as tone, stress, or nasalization) to either a neutral base or a base with a preexisting suprasegmental pattern.

Links: [{"title":"Morphology (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Morphophonology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphophonology"},{"title":"Morphological derivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_derivation"},{"title":"Morphological typology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_typology"},{"title":"Morphological analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_analysis"},{"title":"Morphological parsing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_parsing"},{"title":"Nonconcatenative morphology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonconcatenative_morphology"},{"title":"Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistics"},{"title":"Morpheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morpheme"},{"title":"Inflection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about morphological processes in linguistics:

## Overview

In linguistics, morphology is the study of words, including the principles by which they are formed, and how they relate to one another within a language.(no content)Most approaches to morphology investigate the structure of words in terms of morphemes, which are the smallest units in a language with some independent meaning.

## Main Types of Morphological Processes

### Inflection and Derivation

Rules of word structure are either inflectional rules or rules of word formation. The generation of the English plural dogs from dog is an inflectional rule, and compound phrases and words like dog catcher or dishwasher are examples of word formation.(no content)Morphological derivation is the process of forming a new word from an existing word, often by adding a prefix or suffix, such as un- or -ness. For example, unhappy and happiness derive from the root word happy.

### Nonconcatenative Morphology

Beyond simply adding prefixes and suffixes, there are other morphological processes:

- Base modification or ablaut is a form in which part of the root undergoes a phonological change without necessarily adding new phonological material.
- Reduplication is a process in which all or part of the root is reduplicated.
- Truncation, deletion, or subtraction removes phonological material from the root.

### Morphophonology

Morphophonology is the branch of linguistics that studies the interaction between morphological and phonological or phonetic processes. Its chief focus is the sound changes that take place in morphemes when they combine to form words.

Links: [{"title":"Metathesis (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metathesis_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Metathesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metathesis"},{"title":"Quantitative metathesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_metathesis"},{"title":"Talk:Metathesis (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Metathesis_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Slavic liquid metathesis and pleophony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_liquid_metathesis_and_pleophony"},{"title":"Epenthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epenthesis"},{"title":"Talk:Slavic liquid metathesis and pleophony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Slavic_liquid_metathesis_and_pleophony"},{"title":"Speech error - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_error"},{"title":"Metaphony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphony"},{"title":"Metalinguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metalinguistics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what metathesis is in linguistics:

## Definition

Metathesis is the transposition of sounds or syllables in a word or of words in a sentence. The term comes from Greek, meaning "to put in a different order."

## How It Works

Most commonly, it refers to the interchange of two sounds or syllables within a word. For example, in English, words like "ask" may be pronounced as "aks," where the "s" and "k" have swapped positions.

## Examples Across Languages

Metathesis appears in various languages in different ways:

- **French Verlan**: Deliberate metathesis occurs extensively in the informal French pattern of speech called verlan, where new words are created from existing words by reversing the order of syllables.

- **American Sign Language**: In American Sign Language, several signs which have a pre-specified initial and final location can have the order of these two locations reversed in contexts which seem to be purely phonological. For example, the sign DEAF, prototypically made with the "1" handshape making contact first with the cheek and then moving to contact the jaw, can have these locations reversed if the preceding sign has a final location more proximal to the jaw.

- **Historical Sound Changes**: The Slavic liquid metathesis refers to the phenomenon of metathesis of liquid consonants in the Common Slavic period, acting on syllables in which the Proto-Slavic liquid consonants *r and *l occurred in a coda position.

## Reduplication in Linguistics

In linguistics, reduplication is a morphological process in which the root or stem of a word, part of that, or the whole word is repeated exactly or with a slight change.(no content)It is used in inflections to convey a grammatical function, such as plurality or intensification, and in lexical derivation to create new words.

### Functions and Meaning

According to Edward Sapir, reduplication is "Generally employed, with self-evident symbolism, to indicate such concepts as distribution, plurality, repetition, customary activity, increase of size, added intensity, continuance."(no content)It is often used when a speaker adopts a tone more expressive or figurative than ordinary speech and is also often, but not exclusively, iconic in meaning.

### Types of Reduplication

There are two main types of reduplication:

- Full reduplication involves a reduplication of the entire word, while partial reduplication involves a reduplication of only part of the word.(no content)In reduplication, the reduplicant is most often repeated only once. In some languages, it can occur more than once, resulting in a tripled form, and not a duple as in most reduplication. Triplication is the term for this phenomenon of copying two times.

### Scope and Terminology

Reduplication is found in a wide range of languages and language groups, though its level of linguistic productivity varies.(no content)Other occasional terms include cloning, doubling, duplication, repetition, and tautonymy (when it is used in biological taxonomies, such as Bison bison).

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about constraint satisfaction in linguistics. Here's what I found:

## Constraint Satisfaction in Linguistics

Optimality theory is a constraint-based theory in linguistics which is primarily influential in phonology. This represents one major application of constraint satisfaction concepts to linguistic analysis.

Additionally, constraint-based theories of language comprehension emphasize how people make use of the vast amount of probabilistic information available in the linguistic signal.(no content)Language users are said to arrive at a particular interpretation over another during the comprehension of an ambiguous sentence by rapidly integrating these probabilistic constraints.

The search results also indicate that "real life" examples of constraint satisfaction problems include lexical disambiguation, which is another linguistic application.

These examples show how constraint satisfaction principles are used in linguistics to model how language systems resolve ambiguity and enforce linguistic rules, particularly in areas like phonology, syntax, and language comprehension.

Links: [{"title":"Finite-state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine"},{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Deterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Regular language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_language"},{"title":"Automata-based programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata-based_programming"},{"title":"Nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Two-way finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-way_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Finite-state transducer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_transducer"},{"title":"Generalized nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Alternating finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternating_finite_automaton"}]

I've completed the web search for "formal language finite state automaton". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A finite-state machine (FSM) or finite-state automaton (FSA) is a mathematical model of computation that is an abstract machine that can be in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time.(no content)The FSM can change from one state to another in response to some inputs, and it is defined by a list of its states, its initial state, and the inputs that trigger each transition.

## Connection to Formal Languages

A set of symbol sequences, called a formal language, is a regular language if there is some acceptor that accepts exactly that set.(no content)Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory.

## Types of Finite Automata

Finite-state machines are of two types—deterministic finite-state machines and non-deterministic finite-state machines.(no content)DFAs and NFAs recognize exactly the set of regular languages.

## Practical Applications

Finite automata are often used in the frontend of programming language compilers, comprising lexical analyzers and parsers that build language tokens and syntax trees from sequences of characters.

I've found comprehensive information about computational linguistics. Here's what I found:

## Overview

Computational linguistics is an interdisciplinary field concerned with the computational modelling of natural language, as well as the study of appropriate computational approaches to linguistic questions.(no content)The field draws upon linguistics, computer science, artificial intelligence, mathematics, logic, philosophy, cognitive science, cognitive psychology, psycholinguistics, anthropology and neuroscience, among others.

## History

The field overlapped with artificial intelligence since the efforts in the United States in the 1950s to use computers to automatically translate texts from foreign languages, particularly Russian scientific journals, into English.(no content)After the failure of rule-based approaches, David Hays coined the term in order to distinguish the field from AI and co-founded both the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) and the International Committee on Computational Linguistics (ICCL) in the 1970s and 1980s.

## Professional Organizations and Publications

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Grammar formal linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Formal grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_grammar"},{"title":"Grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammar"},{"title":"Formal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language"},{"title":"Formalism (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formalism_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Chomsky hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chomsky_hierarchy"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Generative grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_grammar"},{"title":"Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistics"},{"title":"Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language"},{"title":"Traditional grammar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_grammar"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of grammar in formal linguistics:

## Definition and Scope

A formal grammar is a set of rules for rewriting strings, along with a "start symbol" from which rewriting starts.(no content)In linguistics, grammar is the set of rules for how a natural language is structured, as demonstrated by its speakers or writers. Grammar rules may concern the use of clauses, phrases, and words. The term may also refer to the study of such rules, a subject that includes phonology, morphology, and syntax, together with phonetics, semantics, and pragmatics.

## Formal Language Theory

In applied mathematics, formal language theory is the discipline that studies formal grammars and languages. Its applications are found in theoretical computer science, theoretical linguistics, formal semantics, mathematical logic, and other areas.

## Generative Grammar

Generative grammar is a research tradition in linguistics that aims to explain the cognitive basis of language by formulating and testing explicit models of humans' subconscious grammatical knowledge.(no content)Generative grammar began in the late 1950s with the work of Noam Chomsky, having roots in earlier approaches such as structural linguistics.

## Chomsky Hierarchy

When Noam Chomsky first formalized generative grammars in 1956, he classified them into types now known as the Chomsky hierarchy.(no content)The linguist Noam Chomsky theorized that four different classes of formal grammars existed that could generate increasingly complex languages.

## Formal Approaches to Grammar

Formal theories of grammar seek to define the different elements of language and describe the way they relate to each other as systems of formal rules or operations, while functional theories seek to define the functions performed by language and then relate them to the linguistic elements that carry them out.
